monogr.title: A briefe apologie, or defence of the Catholike ecclesiastical hierarchie, & subordination in England : erected these later yeares by our holy father Pope Clement the eyght; and impugned by certayne libels printed & published of late both in Latyn & English; by some vnquie persons vnder the name of priests of the seminaries. VVritten and set forth for the true information and stay of all good Catholikes, by priests vnited in due subordination to the Right Reuerend Archpriest, and other their superiors
monogr.author: Parsons, Robert

div.head: TO THE CATHOLIKES OF ENGLAND MOST VVORTHY OF THIS honorable name, that suffer for profession of that fayth and Religion. THE PREFACE.
div.p:
NOthing in this life could euer happen vnto vs more doleful or vnhappy (right honorable) and worthy seruants of God, then to be forced to write to you Catholikes (our dearest bowels) any displeasing thing against Catholike Priestes our most intierely beloued brethrē. But for so much as the vrgent necessitie which in our former Epistle we haue declared vnto our highest Pastor & in this do bewaile, & lamēt vnto you, hath driuen vs against our wils to make this answere, we thought it expedient to forewarne, and forearme you also in this Preface what is meant thereby, least the matter being otherwise taken then it ought should yeeld to scandal, and thereby ouerthrow you and worke your ruine, which is intended and permirted
by almightie God Father of all mercyes to your trial and greater merit, to which end you are diligenly to consider, that most wonderful no doubt among so many other wonders in the affaires of al mightie God, is that his prouidence, or rather patience (as to mans eies it may appeare) whereby he permitteth; not only his whole church, familie, kingdome, and dearly bought portion to be afflicted continually with tempests, and contradictions in this life, but euery particular man also and member of most merit in the same, and according to the degree of his worthines so is the measure commonly of his suffrings. Both partes may be shewed by infinite examples of a perpetual succession of times, and matters happened from the beginning of Christian Religion, vnto our dayes.Diuerse kinde of aduersaries let out against the church, and all good men. For against the Church in general Christe the author had no sooner planted it, but he opened presently all the gates of hel to set out aduersaries, and enemies to assault it, the Iewes first his owne people before, then the heathen and Pagan Emperors with all their mighte and power, and after those againe (or rather with those) he sent a new kinde of aduersaries neuer heard of in the world before named heretikes, that took vnto them selues the name of the best sort of Christians, and yet further, and besides all this among such as remained Catholike Christians and vnited in profession of one faith, he suffred some to be so troublesome and apt to set debate either vpon ambition, enuie, contention, anger, treason or other like passions, as they were no less
combersome to the Apostles and other true laborers, then if they had byn open enemies.

Yea by this later sort especially were particular good men most vexed, and galled from time to time, for of the others open persecution being knowen enemies they did not so much care, but these men being of there owne bowels, yea somtimes also suffring for the same Religion (as by diuerse epistles of S. Cyprian to them that were confessors,S. Cyprian in epistolis ad Martires and liued discorderly in there prisons is euident) they gaue more affliction to the parties whome they vexed; more ioy and hart to the common enemie, and more scandal and grief to all sortes of theire owne side that lo • ed on.

Wel then (most dearly and tenderly beloued) this was then, and this is now; and this shalbe to the worlds end the state of Gods seruants. Times do change, and men do pas,Psal. 116. Verbum autem Domini manet in aeternum. Christes word must endure for euer, and in this he sheweth himself to be God, he hath put the law ineuitable, Pressaram habebitis, Ioan. 16. Acto 20. you shall haue afflictions & exurgent ex vobis viri loquentes peruersa, euil tonged men shal rise out of you, but what, ad probationem fidei benorum, to proue good mens fayth and constancie,Iacob. 1. and what shalbe the ende qui perseuerauerit vsque in finem hic saluus erit, Matt. 24. hee is safe that shal stand out constant to the end, and is not mooued with these blastes. In patientia vestra possidebitis animas vestras. Wee must saue our sowles by patience,Luc. 21. and not otherwise. But one sentence appertaineth especially to you (o worthy Catholikes) in
this our case.Matt. 11. Beatus qui nō fuerit scandalizatus in me. Happie is he that shal not be scandalized in me, that is, shal not leese his patience or constancie, or good opinion of the cause; for this my permission of contradictions and difficulties for that this is permitted to proue you, and not to ouerthrow you.

Diuers impugnations of the English Cathol. cause.Trewly he that wil consider attentiuely, the difficulties and temptations which this our Catholike cause in England hath had since it was first assaulted by heresie, partely by force and flatterie, and other artes of the open enemie, & thē by the peruerse dealing of some of our owne for many yeares together; but especially of late, shal easely thereby discerne the prouidence of our merciful and almightie Saueour therein, & wel say that we are partakers of the same discipline that others haue passed through before in like case,Hebren. 8. and consequently shalbe also of like good end, and happie succes through his grace, if we haue patience, and longaminitie as they had.

And to say nothing in this place of the open impugnation of enemies which too wel you know, and feele dayly, what mightie difficulties haue those had I pray you, that haue byn our chiefe guides, and leaders in sustaining this holy cause for many yeares? and this from such as should haue chiefly assisted them if this diuine prouidence had not otherwise disposed that they should rather exercise them: diuers pointes you know alreadie, and some more you are like to perceaue by this our Apologie (being driuen thereunto) but not all;Reason of vvriting this Apol. for auoyding further
scandal, which respect of scandal should haue with held vs wholy from putting pen to paper in this case, if the intemperance of some persons (giuen ouer as it seemeth to choler and reuenge) and forgetting both themselues and others, and the times wherein they liue; had not broken forth of late to such exces, as we are forced against our wils to put some stop or brydle to so licentious and scandalous proceedinges least it infect euen the good, and trouble the strongest when they see such enormous matters pas without controlment.

And albeit we do not doubt, but that the more graue, and wiser sort wil consider of thēselues Without our answere, the principal pointes that we can by answering note vnto them, as the extreme passion of these libellers in discending to such kinde of reuenge if they had bin iniured, the most bitter and opprobrious stile of speech against there owne,Pointes to be considered in the libels set forth. nothing sauoring of that spirit that should be in seruants of one God; the nature of libelling & contumelious writing wherin no certaine author, no licence of superiours for printing is named; and wherein worthie men are defamed by name without intention or possibilitie to proue it by lawful meanes, and then what greiuous sin,L. Si quis fa mosum L. 9. tit. 36. causa 5. Lt. c. 1. 2. & • . and censures are incurred thereby not only of the doers but consenters also and spredders of such bookes.

Though we say it may be presumed that euery discret reader of himself wil ponder these pointes, as also what manner of men these be, that haue aduentured to be the authors of so intolerable
a scandal in our English Church, what may be there motiues, what there endes, what there meanes by secret cōbining themselues with the enemie, for defaming such as they most feare & hate, and finally what may be doubted in the sequele, and how disunited these men be from there lawful superiors, and consequently from God also as iustly may be suspected, yet for better informing the reader of diuers particularities falsly, and iniustly set downe in their late bookes or infamatorie libels, which I suppose the more pious sort of men wil haue scruple to read or looke vpon, we are inforced as well for these respects, as for the honor of our nation least we seme to strangers to be more then barbarous, as also for some defence of innocencie excedingly iniured in these writings; to make this necessarie Apologie, but in a far other stile then the authors of these bookes haue vsed (if God assist vs with his grace and holy spirit thereunto) and to the end our Apologie may be the more substantial and autentique and these matters depend not o • only saying or denying, we haue thought good to send into diuerse partes, as well of our Countrie, as foraine Realmes where Catholike English remaine,Informations • ent for about this cōtrouersie. to get such informations as may bee had; with the originals or trew copies of letters, and other wrytinges concerning this affaire, which when they shall come to our hands (as some alreadie haue don) our intention is (God willing) to set downe euery t • ing at some length, for both present, and posteritie to see what God hath don, or permitted in this behalf, and who haue byn
trewly helpers, and who disturbers in our cause, who ioyne with the whole body and who impugne it, and other such particularities which wil easely decide the controuersie, if we be not deceaued.

But for that we are forced to expect yet some longer time, before we can haue these informations together, and in the meane space are much vrged by the request of dyuers good men as also by the in • emperate manner of proceding in the authors of these late bookes (who so euer they be)Reasōs for setting forth this briefe Apologie before the larger. to sert forth somewhat for a stay or stop for that these men cease not to write most oprobriously without all regard of truth or modestie and doe promise more dayly in the same Kynde therefore haue we yeilded to this necessite (though sore against our wils) hoping that shortly the other wilbe ready to succeed also albeit our harty desire should be, that the authors of these infamous bookes, & of this most scandalous diuisiō in our church would so enter into themselues, and Christianly corect there owne doings as both this and that mighte bee spared, and all ioyne againe in the sweet vnion of peace, which is nedeful for our work in hand, and was inioyed by vs before this animositie of a few hath put all a fyre, to theire heauie iudgment no doubt according to the Apostles threat if seriously they seake not to remedie the matter in the time, and we do say of a few,Galatas 5. for that we cannot perswade oure selues that all those who by diuerse occasions are named in these bookes for discontented, haue giuen consent to haue thē writtē in the stile they go in, and much les
to be printed, and published to the world, for we haue a far different opinion of their modestie, and Christian spirit, so as these bookes must needs be presumed to haue byn published eyther by some one or few discomposed passionate people, or by some heretike, or other enemie to dishonor them all, and discredite our cause and nation, and so as to such wee shal answere, and not against our bretheren whome we loue most intyrely, and of whose prayers we desire to be partakers, as them, and we and you all of the sweete, and holy spirite of Iesus our Saueoure; to whome we commed you most hartely this first of Iuly 1601.
